HOW TO MAKE A BARREL POND

Making a pond is the single best way of attracting wildlife into your garden – and if your garden is tiny then so must be the pond.

But a perfectly functioning pond can be made in an old half barrel or even a large bowl, although if you select an earthenware pot it should be glazed on the inside or it will be porous and the water will seep through the sides.

The one feature any container you use to make a pond should have is a wide neck, no narrower than 45cm. It should also be no shallower than 40cm, which will allow room for a few plants.

You can keep this on a patio or any other hard surface but you can also make a small bog garden by setting the container on a square of soil – just 30cm or so greater than the diameter of the container – and plant a hosta in each corner.

Then fill the pond every week so that it overflows down into the soil, soaking the hostas and keeping the earth moist – which they will thrive in.

GETTING STARTED

If you’re using a half-barrel, ideally it will not have a drainage or bung hole. If it does, bung it with cork or a piece of wood.

Although barrels are intended to hold liquid, old ones are likely to leak so always line it with a waterproof membrane.

Any polythene or PVC material will do the job but this is a good chance to recycle plastic sheeting or used compost bags rather than buying more plastic. Fix the lining with just enough staples around the top on the inside to hold it – the weight of the water will also hold it in place. It can be trimmed once it is filled.

Cover the bottom of the liner with a layer of subsoil or aquatic compost about 8cm deep. Cover that with a layer of grit.

Place a large branch or stone in the water so that birds can perch on it to drink and wash.

You can now plant into this layer or rest small baskets of plants on it. Fish can also nuzzle into it to find food.

Every little helps

No matter how small your space, whether it’s a patio or just a window box, you can grow plants that will give a warm welcome to wildlife, says Monty Don

There is an image of a ‘proper’ wildlife garden having mature trees, a tangle of lovely shrubs and undergrowth, perhaps a charming flowering meadow and borders full of flowering pollinating plants in summer and seed heads rimed with frost in winter.

This sort of garden obviously does exist and is certainly very good for both humans and wildlife. But it is not most people’s reality.

British gardens are getting smaller and smaller – the average size fell from slightly under 17 square metres in 1983 to just 14 square metres in 2015.

In old money that means the average garden is 15 feet long by 10 feet wide, and given that many gardens are appreciably bigger than that, many are also appreciably smaller. It seems we are running out of space.

But that does not mean that you cannot actively encourage and enjoy wildlife in your garden, however small the plot happens to be.

The elements to include in an effective wildlife garden remain the same but are scaled down in size. These important elements are long grass, water, accessible nectar-rich flowers, berries and seeds, and some cover for birds and mammals.

Butterflies and bees like sunshine, so if you have a sunny aspect, roof garden or window box then this should be planted with plants rich in nectar (such as those in the panel, below right).

Bees like to gorge on the same plants so they are served best by providing blocks of plants rather than a mixture with erratic flowering.

If you have room for one shrub then a buddleia is best for butterflies, not least because it can be pruned right to the lowest buds each spring so that it does not outgrow the limited space.

Don’t forget to make the most of your available vertical space, whether it’s a wall or a fence. If it is not possible to plant directly into the ground – and many houses have a combination of drains and paving against the house walls – then most climbers can be grown in a container.

WILD FACTS

Wildflower seed mixes you can buy online are perfect for a window box – or choose your own wildlife-friendly plants from our list (see right)

Honeysuckle is excellent for a wide variety of wildlife – the flowers attract pollinating insects, including moths, the leaves provide food for caterpillars, and the berries are eaten by birds in autumn. Honeysuckle does best in light shade such as a west-facing wall but will grow in deep shade too.

Any late-flowering clematis such as C. viticella or C. tangutica is also ideal for a container in a limited space because it must be pruned very hard each spring – but it then produces a mass of new growth smothered in flowers from mid-summer right through until autumn.

Nor should you overlook or spurn the common ivy, Hedera helix. It’s an excellent wildlife plant, providing flowers for bees as winter approaches – a time when there are few other blooms around – and really good evergreen cover for little birds such as robins and wrens, as well as insects and even roosting bats.

Many tiny gardens are consumed by shade and are therefore unsuitable for the flowers that most nectar-seeking insects crave. However, there are plants that thrive in deep shade and will nurture an alternative set of creatures.

My own favourites are ferns, which can be just as happily grown in pots as in the soil, and most will relish deep, dry shade. Toads and frogs love the shelter of ferns, as do beetles and small birds.

The soft shield fern, Polystichum setiferum, will grow luxuriantly in the corner of a dry, dark yard and come back year after year without any tending on your part.

But my favourite is Dryopteris filix-mas, the mature plants of which send up fronds 1m tall.

It will grow in almost any position, wet or dry, but is perhaps wasted in anything less than rather dry shade as it is one of the most resplendent of all plants for these tricky garden conditions. Its golden-green relative Dryopteris affinis is slightly more fancy but certainly no less tough.

Bulbs make very good companions for ferns, and snowdrops will grow in light shade, as will Cyclamen coum, which flowers in mid-winter.

Many crocuses flower in shade, and Anemone blanda and Anemone nemorosa also grow and flower happily in shady spots. All these flowers are greedily fed upon by insects at a time of year when little else is flowering.

A few years ago I helped a young couple in Stoke to transform their truly minuscule garden – it was a narrow passageway with a paved area about 2 metres square – into a little paradise. I say ‘helped’ but in truth I did little more than murmur encouragement. The work and skill was all theirs.

One of the things that they were keen to do was to encourage insects and birds, and so they created a living roof. The concept of a living, or green, roof where plants grow naturally in very thin soil on the roof to create a little aerial garden is delightful.

However, it has been quite tricky to execute. In the past I have made living roofs by building a framework and planting into it, which involves quite a lot of engineering as well as horticulture.

But our couple in Stoke simply ordered a vegetation mat – a layer of fibrous organic material with plants already sown into it – which can be cut to size and unrolled onto a roof. Once installed and given a sprinkle of water there was nothing more to be done. And it looked great.

You can buy different types of these mats – ones based on grasses, others dominated by sedums and others filled with wildflowers. All the details about these products are freely available online.

Little pond plants

All these are wildlife-friendly options for a container pond.

Water Lilies

Water lilies tend to prefer deeper water and many grow quite large but there are very small ones that are ideal for a container pond.

Make peace with pests

Prevention is better than a chemical cure when it comes to garden nasties, says Monty Don

Many of the letters and emails I receive from you ask how to kill or eradicate some pest or disease that your garden is afflicted with. The best answer is always the same – try to avoid it in the first place.

This is not much short-term help but is definitely the best long-term solution. And the best way to go about this is to encourage a healthy garden rich with wildlife and self-regulating predators and therefore pests for them to feed off.

Another way of putting it is that organic gardening is mostly about maintaining a healthy, self-balancing mini-ecosystem of which you are a small part.

By and large, you have very little to do as it will sort itself out. The more you interfere – and with the greatest of respect, most of us do so extremely clumsily – the more likely you are to upset that natural balance.

Every garden has to establish its own balance dependent upon its circumstances, and there is no one true way that fits all solutions. But there are a few key rules that will help:

■ Accept a level of predation and disease. Perfection is unobtainable and blitzing the symptoms of problems with chemicals simply exacerbates the problem and creates a vicious cycle. If the garden is fundamentally healthy and beautiful, then tolerate and welcome life as it is lived rather than a fantasy of what it might be.

■ Do not fight nature. You will lose. Instead, work with nature and everybody wins.

■ Remember that you must have some pests in order to maintain a supply of predators. For example, if you want birds, beetles, hedgehogs and toads to eat your slugs then you must have some slugs at all times, to attract these predators into your garden.

■ Accept the prevailing weather or conditions. In warm, wet weather we are bound to have lots of fungal ‘attacks’ on our plants. When plants grow quickly and have plenty of nutrients their lushness will attract aphids and other sap-suckers to feed on this extra-juicy, unnatural growth. You have to accept that some forces are bigger than you and roll with it.

■ Be patient. A healthy organic garden is one that is finely balanced according to the very specific circumstances of each plot. This can take up to three years to establish, and during that transition period there may well be radical imbalances that seem disastrous. Hang on in there...

■ Avoid any kind of monoculture – that is, growing one type of plant. Combinations of plants, whether floral or edible, that share the same growing situation and conditions will always be more healthy than the same plants grown in single-species units.

■ Grow everything hard. The more you mollycoddle any plant, the less equipped it will be to resist the ravages of weather, disease or pests, so make sure you only feed plants when they are clearly ailing. At Longmeadow, our garden in Herefordshire, we never feed anything once it is planted out.

■ Grow plants that would naturally thrive in your garden, as pests are much less likely to damage them. One of the oddities of British gardening is our desire to grow exotic species from the other side of the world that loathe our climate and conditions. This is just asking for trouble!

■ Plant small. The sooner a plant adapts to your soil ecosystem, the better it will grow both in terms of speed and health. Raise as many of your own plants as possible from seed, cuttings and division, and regard the first few growing seasons as an investment in a healthy, long-lasting future.

But if you must act...

There are home-made sprays that you can use as a final measure. For the record I do not use any of them and my garden is by and large very healthy!

STINGING NETTLES

Nettles are a good fertiliser and help your compost heap break down. They also attract butterflies and other beneficial insects into the garden and can be used as an insecticide.

Gather 225g (8oz) young nettles and soak in a bucket of water for a week. Strain and use the liquid to control aphids on roses and the celery leaf miner. Add the mushy nettles to the compost heap.

RHUBARB

The oxalic acid in rhubarb leaves is a safe control agent for aphids, particularly on roses. Cut 450g (1lb) rhubarb leaves, place in an old pan with 1.1ltr (2pt) water and boil for half an hour, topping up as necessary. When cool, add 1tbsp of soap flakes dissolved in 275ml (9½fl oz) warm water. Stir and use undiluted as a spray.

HORSETAIL TEA

If you have a horsetail weed (Equisetum arvense) problem, there’s a bright side to it because an infusion of the weed makes a fungicide for control of mildew on strawberries and other crops, and checks rust on celery and celeriac.

Collect the horsetail – foliage, stems, rhizomes and all – and for each 30g (1oz) pour on 1.1ltr (2pt) hot, but not boiling, water, and leave for 24 hours. Strain the ‘tea’ and use undiluted.

MILK

The enzymes in a solution of fresh milk (no stronger than one part milk to two parts water) sprayed on plants will attack mildew. A stronger solution will result in a foul smell as the milk goes rancid.

item.title: Victoria star Margaret Clunie on secrets, scandal and a very daring duchess
item.description: I scarcely recognise the lady before me without her ringlets. I am having an audience with actress Margaret Clunie, who portrays Harriet, Duchess of Sutherland in ITV’s Victoria.
item.content:encoded:
Ahead of tomorrow’s festive special, Victoria actress MARGARET CLUNIE reveals what makes her on-screen lover so beguiling, why being on set felt like boarding school and how she reckons Prince Albert and his queen have influenced today’s young royals

I scarcely recognise the lady before me without her ringlets. I am having an audience with actress Margaret Clunie, who portrays an actual lady – Harriet, Duchess of Sutherland – in ITV’s acclaimed period drama Victoria.

Of her ‘spaniel hair’ (her words, not mine) in the show, Margaret, 30, says ruefully, ‘The ringlets are clipped in. They tried so hard in the first series to make my hair curl, but it is so pin-straight that in the second series they said, “We give up – this year, clip-ins.”’

Playing the duchess can be a labour of love. ‘Wearing corsets is horrible. They are so restrictive. Now I understand why women were described as ‘becoming hysterical’ back then: it was because they couldn’t breathe, or eat!’

But Margaret, a graduate of Oxford School of Drama, who hails from Rickmansworth, Hertfordshire, is up to the challenge. A willowy brunette, she has an intense gaze – which she has put to good use as the brooding duchess – but this belies an easy manner and a tendency to erupt in giggles.

She has relished taking on the role of Harriet, who will next appear on our screens in tomorrow’s much-anticipated Christmas special. The drama has been a hit, attracting some five million viewers, with the first series overtaking BBC’s Poldark in the coveted Sunday-night slot.

The work of writer/producer Daisy Goodwin, it takes place in the 1840s – during the early years of Queen Victoria’s reign – and chronicles the trials and tribulations, personal and political, of the young queen, her husband Prince Albert and her court, of which Margaret’s character is an integral part.

As the queen’s Mistress of the Robes – ‘which roughly translates as the person who picked out her jewellery and was in charge of doing the rotas for her ladies in waiting, like a 19th-century version of a Google calendar’ – Harriet was ‘basically, her right-hand woman’.

Margaret admits to having had ‘a shaky grasp’ of that period of history. ‘I think I learned about it at school when I was 11.’

She has since brushed up on her knowledge. ‘I would have liked being a Victorian – taking life at a slower pace and the lack of social media would be blissful. I love writing letters.

Also, the high glamour of the era: everything was an occasion and people really made an effort; now, if you’re going out you just throw on jeans and text to say you’ll be ten minutes late.’

She particularly enjoyed ‘delving into’ the character of the duchess – ‘a force of nature and lifelong friend of the queen who had a super-glamorous life; she was close to [Prime Minister] Gladstone, hosted diplomats and lived in beautiful homes’.

Harriet has been a hit with viewers, with part of her screen appeal owing to the forbidden romance that plays out between her and Prince Albert’s elder brother Ernest, ‘a bad boy with a heart of gold’.

It is this smouldering love affair that has, in my opinion, made the drama so gripping. Can Margaret see the attraction of naughty Ernest, as compared to the more serious Prince Albert? ‘Totally! I would go for the bad boy every time – they’re the most exciting,’ she laughs. ‘I think if you’re a charmer, you go very far in life.’

Harriet and Ernest’s relationship was left on a knife-edge at the end of the second series: she escaped the court to get away from the heat of their attraction, then returned as a widow after her – dull – husband, the Duke of Sutherland, was killed in a riding accident.

Ernest planned to propose to her, until he discovered that the syphilis he thought he had cured (with mercury vapours) had returned, and so he jilted her.

‘I really feel for Harriet,’ says Margaret. ‘Her marriage wasn’t satisfying, but she had to stick with it [although the attraction between her and Ernest was potent enough to be noticed by Prince Albert and others].

It’s pretty ballsy that she dared to want happiness, an outrageous concept for a woman in Victorian times. It was hard not to think [before the duke died], “Just divorce him.” We are so lucky to live in an age where you are allowed to make changes.’

This tangled romance is set to take centre stage in the Christmas special, with the storyline continuing six months on from where we left off. Margaret is careful not to divulge too much.

She offers that ‘there will be everything you would hope for from a big Victorian Christmas: ice skating, lots of children and the most beautiful trees, eight massive ones, all decorated with exquisite handmade ornaments; there’s an amazing scene where they do the big reveal’.

(This is only fitting, as Victoria and Albert are credited with popularising the tradition of Christmas trees, along with other festive touches.)

Something tells me, though, that the episode won’t be all yuletide cheer. Margaret nods. ‘There’s a bit of everything, joy and sorrow. Poor Harriet has quite an up and down Christmas; she’s humiliated, broken-hearted and pretty annoyed with Ernest. It’s fraught. They do get a bit saucy. But even back then, the physical side of a relationship mattered – and he has syphilis, so it will be difficult.’

Margaret concedes that this love story may be only loosely based on historical fact. ‘I’m not sure what really happened or how many times they met.’ But she thinks that Goodwin’s storyline was a stroke of genius.

‘Every show needs a scandalous romance. That slow, forbidden love is so much fun to film. Everything is unsaid and implied. There’s so much delicious subtext. People used to communicate feelings that could not be voiced by touching their wrists. Nowadays, everything is so unsubtle and it all plays out on social media. There is something so alluring about how it all bubbled away beneath the surface back then. My favourite scene is where Harriet is practising archery and Ernest comes along and delicately moves her hip, supposedly to help her form. It is so sexy.’

There’s also a lot of highly charged piano duet playing, though Margaret admits, ‘We have a fake piano where you press the keys but no sound comes out. Thank goodness, as I never got further than grade one.’

Off screen, Margaret has a close friendship with actor David Oakes who plays Ernest. ‘He is lovely. We worked together three years ago on Endeavour [a detective drama and prequel to the popular series Inspector Morse]. When he got the part of Ernest, after I had been cast, he rang to tell me and I was whooping with excitement.’

The atmosphere among the cast is jolly, with filming in Yorkshire for six months a year. ‘We stay in a lovely hotel in Harrogate and have a set in an aircraft hangar nearby. It is like boarding school; the hotel lobby is our common room.’ (Margaret attended an independent girls’ school where she boarded in her final year.)

‘I loved it and now I have that experience all over again. We have great restaurants and Turkish baths where we go in our free time, though mostly we just sit around drinking endless cups of tea and coffee.’

Jenna Coleman (who plays Victoria) is ‘lovely and always carries delicious snacks which makes her very popular on set, where everything revolves around eating. She is very petite – and I am quite tall – so we make a funny pair. The first time my dad saw me on the show he rang to ask why I was standing on a box. I wasn’t – I was just standing next to Jenna.’

She insists that actor Tom Hughes, who plays Prince Albert, and is Jenna’s real-life boyfriend, is nothing like his on-screen alter ego. ‘Albert is serious and intense, but Tom is hilarious.’ She is full of praise for Rufus Sewell (Lord Melbourne). ‘You learn so much by watching him – he can portray an entire emotion just by twitching one corner of his mouth.’

And Dame Diana Rigg (Duchess of Buccleuch) is ‘brilliant. She recites random poetry off by heart, tells us all what to do and then says, “You’re welcome, darling.”’ Nell Hudson, who plays Victoria’s dresser Miss Skerrett, was already a ‘great friend’ from drama school. ‘When we aren’t filming, we text each other constantly – we have a very active WhatsApp group.’

The set is also rife with pranks; in one notable episode where the Victorians dealt with a rat epidemic, 25 live rats were brought on set and one joker started a rumour that only 24 had been rounded up at the end. ‘For days, I was visualising their horrid pointy noses and having nightmares. Thankfully, it turned out to be a big lie, which someone thought was funny.’

Like Victoria and Albert, Margaret is blissfully newlywed herself, having married her beau of nine years, musician Tom Bull, in December last year. It was a Christmas-themed London wedding; she wore an off-the-shoulder gown ‘with a sparkly thread running through’, custom-made for her by the fashion label Eponine, for whom she has modelled.

‘I totally relate to how in love Victoria and Albert were,’ she gushes. ‘No one tells you what a thrill it is when you get home from honeymoon and it hits you.’ But while Victoria can’t bear to be parted from Albert, Margaret has not found her filming schedule – and the weeks spent up north – an issue. As a fellow creative, Tom ‘gets it’, and she returns to their South London home most weekends.

‘FaceTime is key. We are very supportive of each other. Neither of us has ever done the nine to five, so this is our normal. If Tom’s band has a gig on a Saturday night, I’ll think, “Great, I can hang out with the girls.”’

When the pair are together, they ‘do fun creative stuff’, such as going to the theatre and cinema and cooking together. ‘I’m working my way through the River Cafe Cook Book. My next goal is to make homemade pasta.’

For her recent 30th birthday, Tom treated her to a night at Cliveden, the famously grand country house hotel where the real Duchess of Sutherland lived for a time. ‘We stayed in the Sutherland Suite and they made a big fuss of us; it was so spoiling. There’s an amazing painting of Harriet in the restaurant.’

Margaret had a happy, straightforward upbringing. She has an elder sister, Alex, who works in the art world – ‘she produces amazing light installations’ – though neither of her parents is creative. ‘I don’t know where our passions for art and drama came from. I can’t say they encouraged it, though they are very proud. My dad is retired – he worked as a consultant and mum was a medical secretary.’ As a child, Margaret was ‘always in all the school plays and choirs’.

MUSTS FOR MARGARET

Motto Fail to prepare, prepare to fail.

Signature dish I try to be healthy, but I make a mean macaroni cheese with extra bacon.

Fitness I hate the gym; I’m more about getting in the bath with a glass of wine. I was rubbish at sport in school, and that has stuck with me. Pilates is the only exercise I’m good at.

Listening to I always have BBC 6 Music on in the background; I love the range: it will have opera one minute and trance the next.

Reading I cannot wait for the follow-up to Philip Pullman’s The Book of Dust and I have just finished Daphne du Maurier’s Rebecca – oh my Lord, it was good.

Holiday hotspot My honeymoon to Myanmar, for the lovely people and beautiful, unspoilt scenery.

Beauty secrets I’m addicted to watching Instagram beauty tutorials and swear by Eve Lom cleanser and a Deciem brightening serum.

Fashion faves I recently attended the Erdem show, which was amazing. I love Burberry for the English-heritage vibe and Gucci for sparkly stuff. They made my wedding shoes – I felt very smug, even though no one could see them under my dress!

After graduating with an English degree from Newcastle University she applied to drama school and the rest is history – though it hasn’t been easy. ‘I have had so many jobs – waitressing, retail… I would get small television parts and think I’d made it, and then a year would pass before the next one.’

Then Victoria came along. ‘This has been my big break. I feel so lucky to have been in both series.’ Margaret would also like to turn her hand to comedy again; one of her earliest jobs was a part in A Young Doctor’s Notebook & Other Stories, set in revolutionary Russia with Daniel Radcliffe and Mad Men’s John Hamm. ‘I was totally overawed by both of them but they were so kind and helpful.’

And she dreams of performing Shakespeare on stage. For now, though, a third series of Victoria is top of her wish list (something viewers will be rooting for, too).

As someone who has made her name in a drama about the royal family, what does she make of our current crop of royals, I wonder?

‘Is it OK to say that I really like them?’ she asks sheepishly. ‘I think they get a hard time. You can’t say a bad word about the Queen – a woman in her 90s who has devoted her entire life to her country – and I have a lot of respect too for the new wave of young royals and the way they’re choosing their partners for love, such as Prince Harry and Meghan Markle. I know it was a long time ago, but I wonder if this shift in thinking – away from who you should marry to who will make you happy – started with Victoria and Albert and their famously loving marriage.’

It remains to be seen if happiness will be on the cards for the Duchess of Sutherland this Christmas, but I have no doubt – as Margaret departs with a flick of that perfect straight hair – that the lady who plays her has it in abundance.

The Victoria Christmas special Comfort and Joy is on ITV tomorrow at 9pm

item.title: That's another wife mess... we've got ourselves into! The author of a new book on Laurel and Hardy reveals the chaotic love lives of the comedy duo
item.description: New Year’s Day, 1938, and the comedian Stan Laurel – one half, with Oliver Hardy, of the most beloved comedy duo the world has ever known – is snoozing in bed with his new bride.
item.content:encoded:
The writer of a new book about the comedy pair explains how their multiple marriages were crazier than any of their movies

New Year’s Day, 1938, and the comedian Stan Laurel – one half, with Oliver Hardy, of the most beloved comedy duo the world has ever known – is snoozing in bed with his new bride. He is hung over, and possibly even still drunk, because he would not have married this woman otherwise.

Her name is Vera Ivanova Shuvalova, but she usually goes by her stage name of Illeana. She is a Russian gold-digger of the worst stripe, as well as an appalling alcoholic.

She travels with a woman named Countess Sonia, who claims to be descended from Russian royalty and may or may not be Illeana’s mother.

Laurel’s introduction to these women has come through Roy Randolph, a Hollywood dancing master only recently acquitted of sexually assaulting a young actress. There is little money for Randolph in giving dancing lessons, but more in introducing his Russian friends to a movie star, especially one who is building up a track record of broken marriages. Which is how Laurel has ended up in Yuma, Arizona, married to a woman he barely knows. His head is thumping.

He thinks it may be the booze, until he opens his eyes and realises that the sound is coming from elsewhere. Someone is knocking. Someone is shouting. There are many ways in which a man might wish to be woken on his wedding night, but a voice screaming ‘Bigamist! Bigamist!’ at his hotel room door is almost certainly not one of them.

Illeana, the third Mrs Laurel, is about to meet her predecessor. While Laurel and Hardy often appeared innocent, even child-like, on screen, their personal lives were difficult, complicated and laced with tragedy.

Now, as they are set to be rediscovered by a new generation with the release next year of the film Stan And Ollie, with Steve Coogan as Stan Laurel and John C Reilly as Oliver Hardy, it is ironic to view the pair’s films and see how often their characters are depicted in unhappy marriages, given the misery both men suffered – and sometimes caused – in their personal lives. As their lawyer, Ben Shipman, put it after their deaths: ‘Such sweet men. But oh, the problems they could get into! Particularly Stan, but Babe [Hardy’s nickname] too.

And most of it was women trouble…’ Oliver Hardy was married three times. His first wife was an older woman named Madelyn Saloshin, whom he divorced messily in 1921 in order to marry a younger actress, Myrtle Reeves. He should have been careful what he wished for. If there is such a thing as a genial alcoholic, then Myrtle Reeves wasn’t it. She spent their marriage repeatedly being committed to, and escaping from, sanatoriums.

At one point she locked herself in a hotel room and threatened to jump from a window, all in full view of police, firemen and a gaggle of newspaper reporters. Hardy did his best for Myrtle but found her alcoholism impossible to live with, and by 1929 he had commenced an affair with a divorcee named Viola Morse, who had a young son.

Hardy’s relationship with Viola would persist, on and off, for a decade, until he eventually divorced Myrtle and married his third and final wife, Lucille Jones. Heartbroken at the break-up of their relationship, and depressed by the sudden death of her son, Viola took an overdose of sleeping pills and crashed her car, though she survived.

But Hardy paid a high price for any sins he might have committed against his ex-wives. Madelyn returned to pursue him for money, as did an increasingly unhinged Myrtle, leaving him virtually broke by the end of his life. Even as he lay on his deathbed in August 1957, deprived of the power of speech and reduced by illness to a thin, frail figure, Myrtle tried to have legal papers served on him.

The process server she sent was so ashamed that he left the house with the papers still in his pocket.

But if Hardy’s relationships with women were complex, Stan Laurel’s were so convoluted as to be almost beyond belief. In 1919, when he was still Arthur Jefferson, he met an Australian actress, Mae Dahlberg, while working on the vaudeville circuit in the US and Canada.

Mae claimed to be a widow, despite the fact that her husband Rupert was alive and well, if conveniently elsewhere. Mae became Jefferson’s common- law wife. When he changed his name, she styled herself Mae Laurel, although they never married.

Mae was older than Laurel, and nowhere near as talented. When he moved to Hollywood, she came with him, but by 1925 Laurel was in love with another actress, Lois Neilson. When it became clear to everyone that Mae was holding Laurel back both in his career and his love life – to everyone, that is, except Mae – she was paid to disappear.

And then Laurel’s love life started to get really complicated. It’s worth going back to those early Laurel and Hardy films (many of them can be viewed online) to get an idea of just how handsome Stan Laurel was in his younger days. He had very blue eyes, and women seemed to find him irresistible.

Even as he and Lois, whom he married in 1926, were expecting their first child together, Laurel had already begun an affair with a French actress, Alyce Ardell. Laurel and Lois divorced in 1934, a decision he always regretted.

Even after quickly marrying Ruth Rogers, a young widow, in 1935, he continued trying to woo Lois back, which may go some way towards explaining why that second marriage lasted only two years.

The disastrous union with Illeana followed. It endured for a year, during which Ruth followed her gatecrashing of the honeymoon by repeatedly sending fire engines to the couple’s home to put out non-existent blazes in the dead of night, and Laurel dug a grave in his back yard with the stated intention of killing Illeana and burying her in it, possibly along with Countess Sonia and Roy Randolph.

Incredibly, after divorcing Illeana, Laurel and Ruth remarried. It was clear that they’d made a mistake, but the marriage still dragged on for five years. Yet even as she was divorcing Laurel for the second time, Ruth described him to the court as a ‘swell fellow’. He just, she said, didn’t know what he wanted. Laurel’s final marriage, to another widow, Ida Raphael, lasted for almost two decades, and it was she who was beside him when he died.

He spent his last years living in a three- bedroom apartment in Santa Monica, California, writing letters, greeting fans and creating routines for his late partner that would never be performed. When he died, his old friend Buster Keaton wept uncontrollably at the funeral. ‘Chaplin wasn’t the funniest,’ Keaton said. ‘I wasn’t the funniest. Stan Laurel was the funniest.’

‘he’ by John Connolly is published by Hodder & Stoughton on August 24 at £16.99

Back on the big screen... aha!

With Steve Coogan as put-upon Stan Laurel and John C Reilly as tubby, overbearing Oliver Hardy, Stan And Ollie has an unusual take on comedy’s most famous double-act. Produced by BBC Films, the recently completed biopic focuses on a tour of Britain the bowler-hated duo mounted in 1953.

They didn’t know it yet but this was to be their swansong. The turbulent circuit of regional variety halls would unearth long-buried resentments, but also remind them what it was that bound them together. ‘It’s a love story between two guys who realise they can’t live without each other,’ explains director Jon C Baird (Filth).

In researching their story, screenwriter Jeff Pope was amazed to find little information about their off-screen lives. ‘I have not treated the boys with kid gloves or looked at them through rose-coloured specs,’ he says. For the actors it presented a big challenge. Not only embodying the deep emotional bond that made the comedy possible, but mimicking those distinctive mannerisms that made them Laurel and Hardy.

Step Brothers star Reilly’s physical transformation is uncanny, with the actor wrapped in a fat suit and given a prosthetic double chin. Coogan was always Baird’s first choice as Laurel, the ‘tortured genius’ who obsessed over the material while the laid-back Hardy was off playing golf or betting on horses.

Coogan was just as obsessed with the Lancashire-born Laurel. Says Baird, ‘He’s very serious about playing this guy. Stan Laurel was a workaholic and his life was dedicated to making people laugh. Steve understands that, he understands how difficult that is.’

Ian Nathan

‘Stan And Ollie’ will be released in 2018

Comedy's dynamic duo

It is almost impossible for us to conceive of just how famous Laurel and Hardy were in their prime. When they travelled to England for the first time in 1932, thousands waited to greet them at Southampton docks, all whistling in unison the pair’s theme tune, Dance Of The Cuckoos.

Ten thousand people crowded the streets of Birmingham to catch a glimpse of the stars. Unlike later duos such as Bud Abbott and Lou Costello, who became estranged over money, Laurel and Hardy only grew more fond of each other as the years went by.

Stan Laurel would outlive Oliver Hardy – ‘Babe’ to his friends – by eight years, but he never worked again after his partner died. Laurel was born Arthur Jefferson in Ulverston, Lancashire, in 1890. He made his stage debut at the age of 16 and never looked back, eventually finding his way to the vaudeville circuit in the United States. Norvell Hardy was born in Harlem, Georgia, in 1892.

He worked as a film projectionist and a singer before finding work as a jobbing actor. Laurel was more driven, with a greater array of skills – acting, directing, writing and editing – but had never been able to find a character or role that captured the public imagination. Only when producer Hal Roach paired him with Hardy did he realise that stardom lay in sharing the limelight. So Laurel would come up with most of the gags, the situations, the stories, and the two men would bring them to life.

Hardy was the better actor: his time as a projectionist had taught him that even the smallest of gestures would appear huge onscreen. Laurel, with his theatrical background, had to learn this subtlety, but there was no bitterness between them. They never argued over money, screen time or women. In fact they hardly ever argued at all.

item.title: When dad doesn't cut it: we investigate whether you should forgive or forget a father who keeps failing you
item.description: Post-divorce, many fathers don't have a close relationship with their children, which can be emotionally damaging. We ask: should you build bridges with your father - or burn them?
item.content:encoded:
Post-divorce, many fathers don’t have a close relationship with their children for a variety of reasons, which can be emotionally damaging. So, asks Anna Moore, is it worth trying to build bridges – or should they be burned?

Last year, for her 25th birthday, Emily’s father took her shopping in London’s West End, followed by dinner at the top of the Shard. Sipping cocktails as the sun set over the city, Emily remembers babbling to him about her new job, her adventures on Tinder, what her friends were up to, and thanking him every five minutes for such a fun day.

One year on, she wonders whether she talked too much, or didn’t thank him enough. She had left on a high, feeling closer to him than she had for years – but months passed with no word from him, no replies to her messages.

Christmas came and went. Then he texted her from a skiing trip, promising to catch up. On her 26th birthday, she heard nothing: no card, no call, not even a text. Emily felt crushed, but not surprised. This on-off scenario has been playing out since her parents divorced when she was eight and her dad left the family home.

Cutting Dad out of my life sounds melodramatic but maybe it would be a relief

Sometimes he would collect her for the weekend as arranged. More often, he failed to show up. Some promises were kept – days out, holidays, school concerts – but usually they were forgotten. Between the ages of 12 and 16, she didn’t see him at all.

‘You’d think by now I’d be immune to the hurt. I don’t know why I still get upset,’ says Emily. It could be because her father has a second family – and dotes on his two younger children.

Then there’s the endless throwaway comments and hurtful comparisons burnt into her psyche over the years (that Emily ‘lacks charm’, that she can’t get away with short hair as her ‘face can’t take it’, that watching her doing ballet when she was little had been ‘hilarious’ – while his second daughter has ‘natural grace’).

‘No matter what people say, or what my rational brain tells me, some part of me believes I’m not good enough and that’s why he behaves like this,’ says Emily. ‘It’s got to the point where sometimes I fantasise about cutting him out of my life – sending an email or a letter asking him never to contact me, blocking his Facebook so I can’t see his new family. It sounds melodramatic, but maybe it would be a relief.’

Sadly, it’s an increasingly common dilemma. Should you give up on an absent, unreliable parent or keep hoping things will get better? Build bridges or burn them? Today, one in eight separated or divorced fathers loses contact with his children, and if they start a new family, one in five loses contact with their elder children.

Almost a third of separated dads say they do not have a ‘close relationship’ with their offspring. But what happens when the children grow up? Sometimes, freed from old family dynamics, relationships can be rebuilt and might even thrive on adult terms. These are the very occasional

longed-for happy endings where everyone is sorry and able to start afresh. More often, though, for adult children like Emily, the relationships continue to lurch along as before. And, for some, there comes a point when it all becomes too fraught, too hurtful and too much effort to continue. But is it ever right to cut ties altogether?

It isn’t hard to find high-profile women who have cut their fathers out of their lives: Kate Hudson, Brie Larson, Christina Aguilera, Kelly Rowland and Adele have all spoken about being estranged from absent fathers. Adele’s dad, Mark Evans, returned to Wales when she was three years old, leaving Adele and her 20-year-old mum in London.

Almost a third of separated dads say they do not have a close relationship with their offspring

Evans’s relationship with his daughter was blighted by his alcoholism, and when she became a superstar he sold his story to a tabloid. Maybe this was the point when Adele gave up on him for good. Accepting one of her five Grammys this year, she thanked her long-time manager who she ‘loved like a dad. I don’t love my dad, that’s the thing,’ she told 25 million viewers. ‘I love you like I would love my dad.’

According to psychotherapist Wendy Bristow, it can take many years before you reach the point Adele has arrived at so publicly. This is because, from childhood onwards, our natural reaction is to idealise an absent parent, most often fathers.

‘Children especially will do this to protect themselves from the pain of them not being around,’ she says. ‘If they’re not there, what does that say about them? What does it say about you? Instead of answering those horrible questions, a child will put that parent on a pedestal.

What results is this syndrome of hope when the parent steps up and disappointment when they let you down. For anyone who experiences that idealisation slowly wearing off over the years, it’s horribly painful.’

As a mother, Jane is seeing this play out with her two young sons, aged six and nine. While her ex-husband has always been unreliable – perhaps keeping his promises to the boys about 50 per cent of the time – since the birth of his daughter with his second wife last year, contact has dwindled to almost nothing.

‘The boys are confused, hurt and heartbroken,’ says Jane, 39, ‘but they still adore their dad. All he needs to do is kick a ball around with them for half an hour and they come home walking taller. Then there’s no contact for weeks, sometimes months. I really don’t know what to do.

Of course I want them to have a good relationship with their dad – but I question this belief in “contact at all costs”. The children can suffer. Just seeing their faces when he cancels yet again leaves me in no doubt about the damage it’s doing to them.

‘Do I cut off contact to save my sons from all the hurt, or persevere in the hope that his behaviour and attitude to them will eventually improve?’ Mothers such as Jane have to walk a very fine line, says counsellor Suzie Hayman, author of How to Have a Happy Family Life.

‘Don’t cut off that absent parent – however tempting – and don’t criticise them,’ she cautions. ‘But you do need to be as honest as you can.’ Never make excuses for the other parent, either. You might think that it’s protecting your child from feeling unhappy, but it allows the idealisation to continue.

‘The children have to know that it’s not their fault, that they are lovable,’ says Hayman. ‘Tell them that their absent parent has the problem, that it’s him – or her if it’s the mother – who needs to change. Make it clear to your children not to have expectations or believe their promises.’

At the same time, try explaining to your ex just how much damage they are causing. ‘Tell them the consequences, that their child is hurt and it’s their fault,’ advises Hayman. When that child grows up, they are free to choose whether or not they want the relationship

to continue, of course. But there’s no ‘right time’ to make that decision, says Hayman. ‘It’s simply when you reach the point where you’re not going to go on hoping,’ she says. ‘It’s when you realise that beating yourself up, exposing yourself to repeated rejection, making allowances or believing excuses doesn’t make you feel better any more – and that hurtful contact is actually worse than having no contact at all.’

It’s not a decision to be made rashly, warns Bristow. ‘And neither should it come from a desire to punish that parent or get him to change,’ she adds. ‘It’s about how it might make you feel, not how it might make your parent feel.’

This is where therapy is advisable. ‘You need to explore your hopes and fears around letting go,’ says Hayman. ‘You need to be clear on what you want from the parent, what they are capable of giving and whether you can accept that.’

Explain the consequences of your parent's behaviour and also what you'd like from them

Writing a letter may help. ‘Shining a light on your feelings allows you to see what you’re unhappy about,’ says Hayman. ‘Don’t make it a rant or a personal attack. Use “I” statements – how the relationship makes you feel – not accusatory “you” ones.

Explain the consequences of your parent’s behaviour and also what you’d like from them – even if it’s just that you would prefer to have a Christmas card every year rather than a grand gesture one year and nothing the next.’

If you do cut contact it’s crucial that you let your parent know. ‘Ask them not to contact you and explain that if they do you’re not going to answer,’ says Bristow. ‘Otherwise you can get caught up in the old pattern of big effort, seduction, silence.

‘It can be liberating and empowering to draw a line and walk away,’ Bristow continues. ‘For years, the relationship may have been on the parent’s terms – turning up when they felt like it – and now you’re taking back control.

It’s not going to wipe away the sadness – it will just mean you won’t have the endless ups and downs and being messed about. It’s not going to make you feel good – but it might make you feel less bad.’

However, there is an alternative – if you can manage it – a ‘middle way’. ‘It’s the hope and the wasted effort that does us harm,’ says Bristow. ‘If you can, opt for low contact: imagine yourself as being Teflon-coated then let go of all expectation of ever getting anything back; then you don’t need to deal with the guilt, drama and “what ifs” of estrangement. Some people can let go internally without having to make a clean break.’

Finding substitutes to fill the father-shaped hole will also help enormously, whatever path you take. Adele’s manager is one person who has helped fill that role in her life, as she made clear at the Grammys. Kate Hudson, who is estranged from her father Bill Hudson, has said that her stepfather Kurt Russell was ‘there for the hard stuff’.

But, as time passes, it’s possible that the estranged, uninterested parent comes knocking. ‘It could be that he has had a sea change and wants to make it up to you,’ says Bristow.

‘Significant life events may have got him thinking – marriage, a grandchild, illness. You may want to ask yourself if he is coming from a place of regret, starting with an apology? Or is he annoyed that you don’t see things his way and thinks he deserves more?’

I told him, politely, that after so many hurts and so many years apart, I didn't want him back in my life but I wished him well

How you react is up to you. Alison, 38, had been estranged from her father since she was 19, when last year he got in contact via Facebook. ‘He’d been quite ill and wanted to meet,’ she says. ‘For years, when I was younger, I’d imagined that big, emotional reunion. He’d been a terrible dad – erratic, with a vile temper – then he met another woman and drifted away.

We lived in the same small town, just ten minutes from each other, but I never saw him – he couldn’t be bothered. ‘I don’t know what I was expecting when I agreed to meet, but what really surprised me was how little I felt,’ she says. ‘Dad quickly became emotional and cried, telling me how ill he’d been, how alone he felt.

He never asked how I was, or how I’d coped over the years. There was no apology or explanation for walking out of my life. It was all about him – pure self-pity. I didn’t feel anything, just awkward – after all those years apart it was like a stranger telling me these things.

‘I have my own life now – a family, career and friends. I did it without him and I don’t need him. Afterwards, he messaged me again and I composed a reply, politely telling him that, after so many hurts and so many years, I didn’t want him back in my life but wished him well. I read it through, then pressed send. It felt right.’

Freed from their fathers

WHAT TO CONSIDER BEFORE DITCHING DAD

● Don’t do it rashly or to punish your father. Does it come from a desire to protect yourself from hurt or to make him sorry? If it’s the latter, then it’s probably not the best course.

● Clarify what you’d like from your father and what he is capable of giving, then ask yourself if you are prepared to accept that.

● Examine any potential regrets – if you do decide to burn bridges, imagine your child or grandchild asking about your father and what you would tell them.

● Consider a low-contact option: letting go of any hopes and expectations without cutting off contact with him altogether.

● Look for other people in your life who can fulfil the role you wanted your father to fill. This often happens unconsciously and you may find that someone is doing it already.
